abstract: How the coming of the Civil War destroyed the two-party system.
snippet: How the coming of the Civil War destroyed the two-party system.
lead_paragraph: Richard C. Vaughan, an attorney in Lexington, Mo., was overjoyed with Abraham Lincoln's 1860 election. Not because the Republican Lincoln won; indeed, he had supported John Bell, the presidential candidate from the Constitutional Union Party. Rather, his joy came from the Democrats' resounding defeat. "The prospect of the final overthrow of the Democracy in Missouri as well as everywhere else," he wrote to a friend, "is to me a source of infinite and irrepressible pleasure in which I know you participate fully."
